thread.title: It's a familiar frustration for Cleveland Browns fans -- Terry Pluto (photos)
thread.title_full: It's a familiar frustration for Cleveland Browns fans -- Terry Pluto (photos) | cleveland.com

author: Terry Pluto, The Plain Dealer
title: It's a familiar frustration for Cleveland Browns fans -- Terry Pluto (photos)
text:
CLEVELAND, Ohio -- You could feel it coming.
That's the problem with following the Browns. There are times when you know ... just know deep in your bones ... that your team won't win.
Especially when the team facing the orange helmets is the Denver Broncos.
Final score: Denver 26, Browns 23. In overtime.
Oh, boy.
"A huge missed opportunity," said Browns quarterback Josh McCown. "I'm disappointed in myself and how we played offensively. The defense played lights out. I saw Karlos Dansby gut it out and get a pick-6. ... We didn't hold our end up."
The Browns were so close to knocking off the undefeated Broncos. They were so close to making their record 3-3 and raising the hopes and heartbeats of everyone who bleeds Cleveland Browns orange.
So close.
"It makes me sick," said McCown.
Fans probably feel the same, because a sad message was delivered: Progress has been made, but not enough to beat a good team like Denver. After six games, the Browns are a very Browns-like 2-4. The last two losses have been on game-ending field goals.
This brought up the old Josh Cribbs line, "We almost always almost win."
WHAT COULD HAVE BEEN
Denver opened the overtime period with the ball.
And Barkevious Mingo ... that's right, Mingo who played only four snaps last week ... the often-criticized Mingo picked off a Peyton Manning pass, giving the ball to the Browns on the Denver 39.
Talk about a great story being written. The Browns were about 10 yards away from being in field goal position. But McCown was sacked, not once but twice.
That's why McCown sounded as if his dog had just died after the game. It's why the videotape in his mind will keep reeling over and over, making him wonder what he could have done differently.
Had the Browns won, Manning would be feeling the same way. The Browns picked off three of his passes. Denver's offense scored only one touchdown.
But Manning put together a game-winning drive when it meant the most. The Browns did not.
BIG PLAYS AT THE END
To be fair to McCown, the defense wilted as Manning drove his team 72 yards in 13 plays to set up the winning field goal. That drive started on the Denver 12.
How about forcing a punt? Instead, the defense buckled.
"If I had been better, we would have won the game," said McCown.
Many Browns on either side of the ball could say the same thing. Coach Mike Pettine did a lot of headshaking after the game. The burden of losing had a fist-like grip on his football soul.
"It's a tough deal," he said. "We were not able to finish it."
Both teams actually seemed to win and lose this game at different points. But in the end, Denver did it right when it meant the most.
Pettine will be in for some second-guessing going for a two-point conversion with 8:07 left. Dansby had returned an interception for a touchdown. The Browns had a 20-16 lead.
Pettine went for two, thinking that he'd be up by six points (two field goals), rather than five with an extra-point kick. But the attempt to score the two points failed.
It would haunt the Browns for the rest of the game.
RUNNING OUT OF COMEBACKS
The Browns kept coming from behind. They were down 10-0 at the half. It was 16-7 Denver early in the fourth quarter. The Browns came back to lead, 20-16. Then fell behind, 23-20.
Regulation ended with the score 23-23.
The Browns are playing hard, but not always smart. That does count for a lot on any given NFL Sunday. They were facing the best defense in the NFL, a nightmare for any quarterback.
McCown was 20-of-39 for 213 yards. He threw two beautiful touchdown passes to tight end Gary Barnidge. But a McCown pass was picked off and run back for a touchdown. A McCown fumble led to a Denver field goal. He was sacked four times, including those two in the overtime.
STAYING THE COURSE
But this is not the time to think for one second about Johnny Manziel taking over at quarterback. Manziel embarrassed himself and the team with his recent driving incident with his intoxicated girlfriend. No one was charged by the police, but the event was disturbing.
The Browns trust McCown. He is keeping them close in every game.
"We just made too many mistakes to come away with the win," said Pettine.
A few plays, the difference between 3-3 and 2-4.
"It's so frustrating to be home and that close and come up short," said Pettine.
